entries: Elk hard geluid hierbinnen zorgt ervoor dat de minotaurussen in gebied F17 op onderzoek uitgaan. De ene gaat waarschuwen {@creature Zegdar|PotA} in gebied F14, en de andere voegt zich zo snel mogelijk bij het gevecht.

entries.name: F17. Ancient Conjury

entries: Het steenwerk in deze kamer is merkbaar anders dan de natuurlijke grotten in de buurt. De kamer is ruw uitgehouwen uit de omringende rots, maar nooit afgewerkt. In het midden van de vloer is een vreemd symbool in de vorm van overlappende cirkels, in de steen uitgehouwen met twee centimeter brede geulen.

Twee {@creature Minotaur||minotaurs} van de Emberhorn stam staan op wacht in deze kamer en verdedigen de voet van de vuurcultus in de fane. Ze hebben de speciale actie Burning Breath (zie gebied F14), omdat ze de "zegen van {@creature Imix|PotA}" hebben ontvangen.

Lang voordat de dwergen hun bolwerk in de grotten boven de fane vestigden, behoorden deze grotten toe aan drow die hierheen werden getrokken door de elementale energieën van het gebied. Deze kamer was een bezweringskamer waar drow demonen opriepen met behulp van de cirkels die in de vloer waren geëtst. Elk karakter dat een succesvolle DC 15 Intelligentie ({@skill Arcana}) check doet, herkent de aard van de cirkels, en dat ze oud en beschadigd zijn tot het punt van onbruikbaarheid.

entries.name: Reinforcements
entries: Elk hard geluid hierbinnen zorgt ervoor dat de minotaurussen in gebied F16 op onderzoek uitgaan. Eén gaat waarschuwen {@creature Zegdar|PotA} in gebied F14, en de andere twee gaan zo snel mogelijk de strijd aan.

entries.name: F18. Drow Tomb

entries: Een vlam danst boven een poel van troebel water in het zuiden en verlicht de kamer. In het noorden staat een sarcofaag, gehouwen uit zwarte, glanzende steen, op een natuurlijk voetstuk. De sarcofaag heeft gecanneleerde versieringen, delicate ribben, en friezen die kruipende demonen tonen.

In het midden van het deksel van de sarcofaag staat een symbool dat de symbolen van de vier elementaire culten combineert - het symbool van het Elder Elemental Eye (zie {@area chapter 1|002|x}). De sekteleden geloven dat de kist heilig is en hebben hem ongemoeid gelaten. Een karakter dat slaagt voor een DC 15 intelligentietest kan de sarcofaag identificeren als een voorbeeld van drow kunstzinnigheid. De sarcofaag bevat alleen stof en botten.

entries.name: Trap
entries: A {@spell glyph of warding} protects the sarcophagus. A character can find the glyph with a successful DC 18 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. Triggered by any attempt to open the coffin, the glyph casts {@spell Mordenkainen's sword} (melee spell attack +10). The sword attacks any creature within 30 feet of the sarcophagus, starting with the triggering creature. It disappears after 1 minute.

entries.name: Flaming Water
entries: The flame burning on the water is fed by natural oil seeping into a tainted pool that is 5 feet deep. The water is undrinkable.

entries.name: F19. That Which Lurks

entries: In the middle of the chamber is a statue depicting an amorphous body and thick tentacles, hunching over as if to feed. A purple crystal the size of a human head represents one alien eye.

Drow carved this chamber and raised this idol to honor Ghaunadaur, a dark god associated with oozes. A character must succeed on a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check to identify this obscure deity.

The "crystal" is worthless glass. Any creature that removes or destroys the stone must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or be subjected to Ghaunadaur's curse. The curse is like a {@spell polymorph} spell, except it turns the offender into an {@creature ochre jelly} that lacks the Split reaction. A {@spell greater restoration} or {@spell remove curse} spell ends this effect.

entries.name: F20. Hall of Battle

entries: This room smells of blood and death. The debris of several recent battles is scattered throughout this rough-hewn chamber. A dozen dead warriors, clearly of the earth and water cults, lie amid a handful of monstrous corpses, such as those of bugbears and ogres. Some of the bodies look like they have been here for months, while others are only days old. A whirlwind of air encased in armor and clutching a flail rushes into view.

This chamber has been a battleground for the elemental cults as they seek to consolidate control of the fane. The Cult of the Howling Hatred presently holds the room, which is guarded by an {@creature air elemental myrmidon|MTF} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}).

When intruders appear, the myrmidon levels its flail at them and asks in a cold voice, "Whom do you serve?" The myrmidon decides whether the adventurers are friends or foes, based on their response to its question and the gear they wear. If the characters look like air cultists and reply that they serve elemental air or the Elder Elemental Eye, the myrmidon might be satisfied. If not, the myrmidon attacks.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The various human corpses in this hall include air cultists, earth cultists, and a pair of fire cultists. No coinage or other valuables remain, but the characters can scrounge up cloaks, surcoats, or robes sufficient to create five air cultist disguises, four earth cultist disguises, and one fire cultistdisguise.

entries.name: F21. Temple of the Elder Elemental Eye

entries: A stone ziggurat capped by a huge altar of black granite stands in the middle of this cavern. At the foot of the altar lies a bound and gagged figure. Fresh rivulets of blood stain the altar and trickle down the steps of the ziggurat. On all sides of the cavern, guttering flames dance atop sluggish pools of oily water. Gusts of wind moan and howl from fissures high in the cavern walls.

This chamber is the Temple of the Elder Elemental Eye, the dark force that lies behind Elemental Evil. The ziggurat dates back to ancient times when drow renegades venerated the Eye, long before the days of Besilmer. The elemental prophets come here to seek visions and boons from the Eye, although it is a fickle and uncommunicative power that rarely responds in any recognizable way.

entries.name: Altar
entries: Any non-evil creature that touches the altar or makes a melee weapon attack against it must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 22 ({@dice 4d10}) psychic damage. The altar has AC 15, 150 hit points, and immunity to acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, psychic, and thunder damage, as well as bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical weapons. As long as the altar remains intact, servants of Elemental Evil (including members of the hour elemental cults) can't be {@condition frightened} while in this room.

entries.name: Flaming Water
entries: The flames burning on the pools are fed by oil seeps beneath the water. The water is tainted and undrinkable.

entries.name: Cult Forces
entries: One of the four elemental prophets is here when the adventurers first arrive. Accompanying the prophet is a handful of subordinates. Choose from the following options, discounting any prophet who has been defeated:

items: {@creature Aerisi Kalinoth|PotA}. The air prophet is accompanied by {@creature Windharrow|PotA} (if he escaped the Temple of Howling Hatred), two {@creature Hurricane|PotA|hurricanes}, and three {@creature Howling Hatred Initiate|PotA|Howling Hatred initiates}.
{@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA}. He is mounted on a {@creature giant crocodile} and accompanied by four {@creature Crushing Wave Reaver|PotA|Crushing Wave reavers}.
{@creature Marlos Urnrayle|PotA}. The earth prophet is accompanied by two {@creature Gargoyle||gargoyles} and two {@creature Sacred Stone Monk|PotA|Sacred Stone monks} wearing gargoyle masks.
{@creature Vanifer|PotA}. The fire prophet has a {@creature flameskull} and two {@creature Razerblast|PotA|razerblasts} under her command.

entries: The prophet knows who the characters are. He or she is also aware of any other prophets the party has faced and defeated, having seen the events in fevered visions. The prophet dismisses any such defeat as the culling the weak, assuring the characters that no such weakness is to be found here.

If it seems in keeping with the prophet's personality (see {@area chapter 7|716|x}), he or she attempts to recruit the characters, saying, "You have shown you are resourceful and have great courage. We can use you. Swear allegiance to me, and I shall show you power such as you have never dreamed of."

entries.name: Sacrifice
entries: If the characters accept the prophet's offer, he or she demands a test of good faith. The prophet and entourage move to a tactically safe position. Then, to prove their sincerity, the new converts must offer the sacrifice. The villains have a {@creature commoner} named Darreth, abducted from Womford weeks ago, as a sacrifice. Darreth is already bound, gagged, and lying at the foot of the altar.

Darreth doesn't know the layout of the fane, but he has met each prophet except the one the characters defeated on the temple level. He can describe their appearance and demeanor, and he can identify the elemental weapons that each one carries. Further, he knows that these weapons are important and somehow connected to places of elemental power called "nodes."

If he is set free, Darreth is brave enough to accompany the characters if they so wish, and also desperate enough to make the trip back to Womford alone if the characters give him directions back to the surface.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each elemental prophet carries an elemental weapon (see {@area chapter 7|74f|x}).

entries.name: Conclusion
entries: Defeating the prophet in the Temple of the Elder Elemental Eye (area F21) causes the two remaining elemental prophets to receive a vision of the defeated prophet's final moments and the final incantations of a summoning ritual they haven't yet attempted. Each surviving prophet retreats into his or her respective elemental node and begins preparations to summon one of the four Prince of Elemental Evil.
Any monsters in the fane remain until the characters defeat them.

entries.name: The Howling Caves
entries: These caves belonged to deep gnomes who had started to explore the Besilmer ruins when the air cult arrived. When the air cult seized the caves below Tyar-Besil, the svirfneblin organized resistance. Their attempt was futile. As soon as {@creature Aerisi Kalinoth|PotA} understood the power of the {@item Devastation Orb|PotA|devastation orbs}, she tested one on the svirfneblin. The resulting cyclone obliterated the outpost, and its chaotic after effects imbued the caves with elemental power which blows through the caves to this day.

entries.name: Cave Features
entries: The area has the following features. Any exceptions are noted in areas to which they apply.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Most cavern ceilings are 30 feet high, and passage ceilings range from 10 to 15 feet high.

entries.name: Light
entries: The Howling Caves are lightless.

entries.name: Wind
entries: Wind continuously moves through the Howling Caves, in whispers or howls.

entries.name: N1. Entrance

entries: A subterranean wind blows north, up the tunnel, carrying distant screams from the south.
The north end of the tunnel forms the bottom of a widening shaft that leads up to area F2 in the Fane of the Eye. The rough walls can be climbed safely.

entries.name: N2. Deadly Pool

entries: The temperature plunges in this cave, which is dominated by a frozen pool. Ice crystals glitter on the walls, floor, and other rock formations. Snow whirls about on strong gusts.

When the characters first arrive, the temperature in this cave is −30 degrees Fahrenheit. The ice is frozen solid and slippery. (See chapter 5, "{@book Adventure Environments|DMG|5|Extreme Cold}," in the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} for rules on extreme cold and slippery ice.) For every minute the characters spend here, there is a cumulative ten percent chance that the temperature shifts dramatically.
When the temperature shifts, read the following:

Suddenly, the air grows very warm. Water rains from above. The ice cracks, and thick waves of steam rise from the pool. Bobbing among the breaking ice, the bloated bodies of small humanoids stare up with wide, dead eyes.

The shift to extreme heat, as described in {@book chapter 5|DMG|5|Extreme Heat} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}, takes only a moment. When the heat begins, the ice cracks at the start of that round and is unable to hold any weight end of the round 3 rounds later. The lake is 12 feet deep and turns to boiling water. A creature that enters the water for the first time on its turn or starts its turn there takes 7 ({@dice 2d6}) fire damage. In addition, steam renders the cave lightly obscured.

entries.name: Floating Corpses
entries: The bodies are the boiled remains of svirfneblin that lived in area N5.

entries.name: N3. Oubliette

entries: Gore spatters the floor and walls of this windy cave, and the floor is strewn with dismembered humanoid corpses. A windy cyclone moves among the remains. A shaft in the ceiling leads up farther than you can see.

The shaft leads to area A18 in the Temple of Howling Hatred. An {@creature air elemental} is bound to this area and cycles beneath the shaft like a red cyclone. Everywhere it moves, it spatters the walls with blood, bone, and viscera.

The corpses are sacrifices to {@creature Yan-C-Bin|PotA}, hurled down the shaft by air cultists. The symbol of elemental air is cut into each victim's forehead. The characters can find an intact head and see the symbol in gory relief.

entries.name: N4. Storm Chasm

entries: A chasm divides the subterranean passageway, which continues on the other side ten feet away. Fog obscures the chasm's depths.

The chasm is 50 feet deep, and the lower 40 feet of it is heavily obscured by fog. At the bottom of the chasm are blunt rocks and cave floor. The walls are rough and can be climbed with a successful DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

The chasm fills with wind, thunder, or lightning at random times. If one or more creatures are in the chasm, have them roll initiative. On initiative count 10, roll a {@dice d20} and consult the following table to determine what effect, if any, occurs in the chasm:

entries.name: Wind
entries: A strong wind fills the chasm for 1 minute. The wind extinguishes open flames in or above the chasm and imposes disadvantage on Strength and Dexterity checks made by creatures in the chasm.

entries.name: Thunder
entries: Thunder momentarily fills the chasm. Each creature in the chasm must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, it takes 10 ({@dice 3d6}) thunder damage and is {@condition deafened} for 1 minute. On a success, the creature takes half damage and isn't {@condition deafened}.

entries.name: Lightning
entries: Lightning momentarily fills the chasm. Each creature in the chasm must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 28 ({@dice 8d6}) lightning damage on a failure, or half as much damage on a success.

entries.name: N5. Svirfneblin Settlement
entries: If the nycaloth is in area N7, the characters hear a horrid, rasping song coming from the eastern passage.

Dwellings carved in the walls of this cavern have been torn asunder by some intense force. Ruins of several dwellings resemble gaps in the walls and piles of rubble. Scores of small humanoid corpses are scattered among the ruins.

This svirfneblin settlement was the test site for {@creature Aerisi Kalinoth|PotA}'s first {@item devastation orb|PotA}. Four {@creature Specter||specters} of deep gnomes who perished here wander the ruins. The power of the air node imbued them with elemental energy, so their attacks deal lightning damage instead of necrotic. They attack any creature that enters the cavern.

entries.name: N6. Breathless Cave

entries: Giant spiders are seized in death among dead cave lizards, giant bats, a carrion crawler, and a female drow decked in fine chain mail, with ruby-pommeled knives at her hips. No injuries are apparent, and the smell of death is fainter than one would expect. At the back of the cave, within ten feet of the drow, a breeze whistles through three tiny fissures in the rock.

The fissures magically pull the air from the cave and the lungs of any creature that comes within 30 feet of the back of the cave. Such a creature must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be unable to breathe. The creature can't breathe normally again unless it succeeds on the saving throw, made again at the end of each minute. A {@spell remove curse} spell also ends the effect, as does {@item bottled breath|PotA} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6|Bottled Breath}).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The drow wears a suit of {@item elven chain} and carries a pair of fine daggers decorated with rubies (1,000 gp each), as well as a scroll of {@spell primordial ward|XGE} (see {@adventure appendix B|PotA|8}). See area N7 for more information on this drow.

entries.name: N7. The Floating Ones
entries: If the nycaloth is alive here, the characters hear a horrid, rasping song coming from the area before they see it.

Two humans, an aarakocra, and a drow hang suspended from hooks connected to chains. Blood pools on the floor beneath them. Beetles scurry along the floor, walls, and down the chains and onto the victims, which faintly struggle, rasp, and moan as a breeze turns them around and around. Debris, including tattered clothing and broken weapons, is scattered against the walls.
This gruesome display is the work of a {@creature nycaloth} that takes sadistic delight in torturing captives. It guards the outer reaches of the Howling Caves against intruders.

entries.name: Prisoners
entries: The prisoners here are in poor condition. Each one is incoherent and has 1 hit point remaining. Healing brings a captive back to his or her senses.

The humans are two {@creature Howling Hatred Initiate|PotA|Howling Hatred initiates} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}) who angered Aerisi one time too many. They're sullen and silent if interrogated. They flee for the surface at the first opportunity.

Feathergale knights captured the {@creature aarakocra}, named Kazra and brought her here for interrogation. She wants only to fly under the open sky once again and pleads with the characters to escort her back to the surface.

The {@creature drow mage}, Balix, is a historian and companion to the dead scout in area N5. They came to see the Fane of the Eye and to find out if surfacers were here, and they walked into a cult ambush. He wants nothing to do with the cults, the surface world, or anything other than returning to the nearest drow community. He uses his innate {@spell darkness} spell to retreat as soon as possible.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Among the debris is a spider silk pouch with 23 pp and a {@item necklace of prayer beads}. The necklace holds one {@i bead of blessing}, one {@i bead of curing}, one {@i bead of summons}, and one {@i bead of wind walking}.

entries.name: N8. Wind Chorus

entries: Wind rushes through this curving natural passage and off into the darkness beyond, howling in a changing pitch as it feeds through the alcoves and fissures of faraway caves.
Occasionally, while here, one or more characters hear whispered lies or hateful howls, as many times as you wish.

entries.name: Whispered Lies
entries: Choose an NPC friend or ally who was or is important to the affected characters. Those characters hear the NPC's voice on the wind, but the voice taunts and whispers of failures, flaws, and negative traits.

entries.name: Hateful Howls
entries: Choose an NPC adversary who was or is important to the affected characters. The voice of the adversary swears vengeance, makes threats, and foretells doom.

entries.name: N9. Mushroom Forest

entries: This cave has an uneven floor covered with toadstools. The toadstool caps are spotted white, purple, green, and blue. Some are as low and wide as forest ferns while others stand as tall as humans, their stems thick as the trunks of trees. Still others shed a faint light, eerily illuminating a sloped passage leading down to the shore of a placid body of water that also glows dimly. Beneath whispering gusts of air, the sound of dripping water echoes.

Among the myriad fungi, several are magical and act as potions if eaten. One aqua-spotted toadstool acts as a {@item potion of longevity}. Two amber toadstools flecked with gray work as {@item Potion of Heroism||potions of heroism}. Three pale lavender toadstools are like {@item Potion of Healing||potions of healing}. These magical toadstools regrow over the course of the next year.

Eating any other toadstool forces the eater to make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw after {@dice 2d4} minutes. Failure indicates the consumer is {@condition poisoned}. A creature {@condition poisoned} in this way can repeat the saving throw at the end of each hour, ending the effect on a success.
The sloping passage to the south leads to area N12.

entries.name: N10. Stalagmite Garden

entries: Wind blows through this weird stalagmite garden. The rock formations are smooth and contorted, their natural forms weathered to be chaotic and abstract.

Supernatural air has weathered the stalagmites such that they form weird images as one moves through the cavern. The characters might see a line of figures struggling to walk against the wind, faces of the dead, or anything else you wish to depict or convey in your campaign.

entries.name: N11. Hero's Tomb

entries: A yellow casket rests on the flat top of a stone column in the middle of a glowing mere.

The natural column rises 20 feet and is slick with water and fungus, so it requires successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks to climb unaided. The casket is covered with a patch of yellow mold (see chapter 5, "{@hazard yellow mold||Adventure Environments}," in the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

Beneath the mold, a Dwarvish inscription on the casket reads, "Here rests Godwyd the Wyrmbane, dragonslayer and peacekeeper." The casket contains dust, bones, a cloven skull and helm, and a battered breastplate. A gleaming shortsword is clutched in the skeleton's hands (see "Treasure" below).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Godwyd's shortsword is a {@item dragon slayer}. Removing the blade causes a low moan to rise from the casket, but nothing else happens.

entries.name: N12. Glowing Mere

entries: Surrounded by tall stalagmites and fungi, a wide, placid pool of water stretches through this elongated cavern. The water glows a soft blue, and in its shallows, silvery fish dart in and out of sight.
The mere is 15 feet deep at its deepest point. The water here is clear and clean.

entries.name: N13a–N13b. Whispering Caverns

entries: This cave has an uneven floor. Wind whispers through the flowstone formations here.
These caves are empty.

entries.name: N14. Air Node's Doorstep
entries: Wind blowing from area N15 intensifies as it passes through this area, extinguishing torches and other open flames.
Several windy tunnels meet at a chasm. Ledges along the cavern walls create natural footpaths above the abyss.

The chasm is 100 feet deep. The strong wind makes walking on the narrow ledges treacherous. Any creature doing so must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check. A creature that fails this check falls from the ledge into the chasm. Normally, the chasm would be easy to climb, but the wind makes it so the climb requires successful DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks. A creature that fails such a check falls from the chasm wall.

entries.name: N15. Windhuggers

entries: A warm wind swirls through this smooth cave, seemingly changing course at random. Nine cultists wearing feathered cloaks stand here with arms outstretched, as though waiting for the wind's embrace or, perhaps, waiting for the wind to carry them somewhere far, far away.

A {@creature Howling Hatred priest|PotA} and eight {@creature Howling Hatred Initiate|PotA|Howling Hatred initiates} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6} for both) are here, but they are too swept up in their "windhugging" to fret about intruders. They attack only if the characters disturb them. This wind here is loud enough that sounds of combat in this cave can't be heard elsewhere.

entries.name: N16. Tortured Cavern

entries: The walls have a smoothed, rippled look about them, as if the stone was melted. Squat stalagmites and elongated stalactites bend and lean in unnatural arcs. A strong draft blows across the rock formations, eliciting a hollow howl.
As the characters explore this area, a {@creature black pudding} pours out of a narrow crack in the wall behind them, cutting off their escape. It fights until slain.

entries.name: N17. Sacrifices
entries: Characters hear the wind and spot the green light here before arriving.

At an intersection of four tunnels, a mighty gale blows from the northern way, making a constant howl. Two braziers burn with green flame, lighting the area. Numerous rock columns join the floor to the ceiling. Severed silk ropes, darkly sodden with blood, sit at the base of three gore-spattered columns. Tied to two other columns are two women, each with a symbol cut into her forehead.

Prisoners are kept here until they can be sacrificed to {@creature Yan-C-Bin|PotA} in area N19. Two {@condition invisible} {@creature Barlgura||barlguras} guard the prisoners. The demons lurk among the columns in the upper reaches of the cave, dropping down to attack intruders who dare free the prisoners. If they spot the characters, the two women warn characters of the "{@condition invisible} demons" that guard them.

entries.name: Light
entries: Two braziers light this area with {@spell continual flame} spells.

entries.name: Prisoners
entries: Two humans are kept here, the symbol of air cut into each one's forehead. One is Nerise Gladham, a farmer (an unarmed {@creature commoner} with 2 hit points remaining). The other is Deseyna Norvael, a high-ranking Waterdhavian diplomat (an unarmed {@creature noble} with 4 hit points remaining) who was part of the Mirabar delegation. Both prisoners want only to escape this area and return to civilization.

entries.name: N18. Royal Guard
entries: The wind is so strong in this chamber and the tunnel leading to area N19 that each creature starting its turn in the area must succeed on a DC 10 Strength saving throw or be pushed 10 feet toward area N17. Flying creatures have disadvantage on the save. From this point on, a creature must spend 2 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves when moving closer to area N19. Flying creatures spend 5 feet of movement instead of 2.

The wind disperses gas or vapor, and it extinguishes candles, torches, and similar unprotected flames in the area. It causes protected flames, such as those of lanterns, to dance wildly and has a fifty percent chance to extinguish them.
The characters spot the green light ({@spell continual flame}) from the brazier here before arriving.

A powerful wind roars through this small cave, causing bits of debris to ricochet off the walls, exploding into dust from the impact. In the middle of the cavern a stone brazier is lit with a steady green flame. Blocking the tunnel to the north are four thin figures in billowing cult robes. The wind doesn't seem to impede them at all.

Four emaciated {@creature Howling Hatred Priest|PotA|Howling Hatred priests} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6})—Aerisi's most devout cultists—guard this area. Periods of sustaining themselves upon only air have warped their bodies. Their eyes bulge from cavernous sockets, and skin stretches across jutting bone. Because of their devotion, they are immune to the wind's effects.

entries.name: N19. Air Portal
entries: Characters hear thunder and see flashes of light as they approach this area.

In the middle of this cavern, spikes of stone jut upward like three immense claws. Between them, a churning thundercloud thrashes with lightning. Thunder cracks, and cascades of tiny rocks tumble from above. Beneath the thunderhead stands a raised area splattered with the blood of many sacrifices.
A silvery window is sometimes visible in the center of the cloud. It opens onto clouds in an endless sky.
If the characters defeated Aerisi, two {@creature Air Elemental Myrmidon|MTF|air elemental myrmidons} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}) defend this cave.

If Aerisi is here but isn't the only prophet still alive, use the "Encounter with Aerisi" section. Use the "Encounter with {@creature Yan-C-Bin|PotA}" section if Aerisi is the only remaining prophet. In either encounter, the air elemental myrmidons aren't present.

entries.name: Encounter with Aerisi
entries: {@creature Aerisi Kalinoth|PotA} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}) stands next to the air portal, protected by an {@creature air elemental myrmidon|MTF}. While attempting to call {@creature Yan-C-Bin|PotA} into the world, she tries to stay out of the characters' reach while casting her destructive spells. The myrmidons focus on thwarting and killing ranged attackers and spellcasters.

Aerisi refuses to flee at this point, and trying to do so through the air portal with {@item Windvane|PotA} would be disastrous. When the characters defeat her, she vanishes in a scream of wind, but {@item Windvane|PotA} remains, as does the portal.

entries.name: Encounter with Yan-C-Bin
entries: When the characters arrive, {@creature Aerisi Kalinoth|PotA} is alone. She holds {@item Windvane|PotA} aloft and cries, "With this key, I call forth my lord and master!" The moon elf then bows as {@creature Yan-C-Bin|PotA} (see {@area chapter 7|728|x}) flies through the portal. The Prince of Evil Air appears as a gaunt, dark-gray man with white hair and glowing eyes. In this form {@creature Yan-C-Bin|PotA} smiles, and his eyes flash with lightning. As Aerisi gloats, {@creature Yan-C-Bin|PotA} focuses on destroying the characters.

entries.name: The Air Portal
entries: The thundercloud surrounds a silvery window, which is a portal to the Plane of Air that leads directly to the steps of {@creature Yan-C-Bin|PotA}'s {@condition invisible} castle. This portal is 30 feet from the floor.

Those who pass through the portal arrive on the steps of {@creature Yan-C-Bin|PotA}'s {@condition invisible} fortress, where {@creature Yan-C-Bin|PotA} comes forth to destroy them. Although {@creature Yan-C-Bin|PotA} can enter the world only when the proper ritual is complete, the characters can easily flee through the portal.

Characters can close the portal only by hurling {@item Windvane|PotA} into it, destroying the weapon in the process. If the portal closes while {@creature Yan-C-Bin|PotA} remains in the world, he is forced back to the Elemental Plane of Air.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Aerisi has decked herself in royal finery. She wears a platinum torc (worth 1,600 gp), gold and sapphire rings (four, each worth 1,000 gp), and a diadem (6,400 gp) from Evereska. She carries {@item Windvane|PotA} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6|Windvane}).

entries.name: The Plunging Torrents
entries: Dangerous waterfalls, sudden deluges, and weird elemental effects fill the Plunging Torrents, a cavernous extension of the Elemental Plane of Water.

entries.name: Torrents Features
entries: The complex has the following features. Any exceptions are noted in areas to which they apply.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Cavern ceilings are 10 feet above the water.

entries.name: Climbing
entries: The walls are rough, slippery stone that require successful DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks to climb.

entries.name: Currents
entries: In locations near steep waterfalls, rapid currents exist. Whenever a creature enters a strong current for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be carried 10 feet in the direction of the current, as indicated by arrows on the Plunging Torrents map. The creature can attempt to swim against the current by making successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks. Such water is {@quickref difficult terrain||3} for all swimmers.

entries.name: Doors
entries: Interior doors are made of stone and have neither locks nor keyholes.

entries.name: Light
entries: The node is dimly illuminated by blue and green glows that radiate from the water.

entries.name: Water Depth
entries: Most water is 20 feet deep.

entries.name: Waterfalls
entries: Waterfalls are 40 feet high. A creature swept over a waterfall takes no damage from the fall. However, at the start of its turn in the lower basin, the creature must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be driven 10 feet underwater and {@condition restrained} there. The creature can use its action to make a DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check, ending the {@condition restrained} condition on a success.

entries.name: Aboleth Whispers
entries: Whenever the characters explore a new area, roll a {@dice d6}. On a roll of 1, choose one character to receive an image of the setting features (but not creatures) in area P4, P5, or P6. The aboleth living in the node is telepathically projecting these images to frighten trespassers and ultimately lure them to its lair.

Whenever a character responds to this telepathic contact, a link is established. The aboleth instantly knows all the character's desires and goals. It then intermittently projects images to the character in which everything the character loves is destroyed by the Cult of the Crushing Wave. After receiving these images, the character must succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw or suffer a random form of short-term madness, as described in chapter 8, "Running the Game," of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

entries.name: Random Encounters
entries: Check for a random encounter every 10 minutes. Roll a {@dice d20} and consult the following table to determine what, if anything, the characters encounter:

rows: 1 {@creature Dark Tide knight|PotA} mounted on a {@creature water weird} (see area P16)

entries.name: Symbol of Water
entries: Within the Plunging Torrents, any creature that has the symbol of water scratched into their flesh gains a swimming speed equal to its ground speed, is immune to the effects of currents, and suffers no negative effects from descending a waterfall. Inscribing the mark deals 1 slashing damage and leaves a scar. Healing magic can remove the scar and the capabilities it grants.

entries.name: P1. Waterfall Basin
entries: De waterval is hier al van verre te horen.

A loud waterfall pours into this mossy cavern. Wet stairs hug the western wall, climbing higher than the waterfall and descending into the water-filled basin. Where the stairs meet the water's surface, an iron post juts at an angle, and a flat boat is tied to it. Tunnels to the northeast and northwest channel the water from the pool. Above the pool, a seven-foot-diameter globe of water hovers in midair.
A character who has a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 10 or higher notices the water symbol engraved above the northeast passageway.
The stairs descend 5 feet beneath the lake surface, ending at a rough underwater ledge 15 feet above the submerged cavern floor. The stairs ascend to area F8 in the Fane of the Eye.

entries.name: Iron Post
entries: The iron post is a recent addition to the cavern, planted haphazardly into the rock of the staircase. When the characters arrive in the chamber for the first time, a punt is moored here.

The punt is a long, flat-bottomed boat equipped with a pole for navigation through the water node. This punt can accommodate up to seven Medium creatures. As part of its movement, a creature can use the pole to propel the punt 10 feet. The punt has AC 8 and 50 hit points. If it goes over a waterfall, it loses 25 hit points and capsizes.

entries.name: Watery Globe
entries: The 7-foot globe of water floats 1 foot above water level and is stationary until a creature touches it, whereupon it envelops the creature and carries it to area P20 via the northeast tunnel (passing though areas P12, P14, and P16). The globe has a flying speed of 10 feet, and a creature contained within gains the benefit of a {@spell water breathing} spell for as long as it remains in the globe. Any time during the trip, the creature inside the globe can swim out of it as an action. The globe carries only the one creature and bursts upon reaching its destination. A globe is immune to damage, though {@item dust of dryness} destroys it.
When the globe is destroyed or leaves this cave, another one rises up out of the water to take its place.

entries.name: P2. Plunging Passage

entries: The current moves swiftly toward a small, rocky island that splits the waterway north and south. The sound of falling water is louder to the south.
The current pulls to the south of the island toward the waterfall leading to area P17. Characters navigating the area by water are pulled south and over the falls unless they take countermeasures.
The waterway to the north flows westward down the passageway, unaffected by the current.

entries.name: P3. Nets

entries: The waterway dead-ends in a long cavern where only the distant sound of the falls echoes off the walls. Nets divide the cavern, spanning the distance between pairs of stalagmites jutting above the water.

Seven {@creature Giant Crab||giant crabs} dwell in this cavern. Three are in plain sight on the rocky ledge to the northwest. Two crabs cling underwater to each span of net. Characters observing the water must roll a successful DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to spot the submerged crabs, which climb their nets to attack any creatures that pass within reach. Once combat starts, all the crabs attack.

entries.name: Nets
entries: Each net draped across the cavern has AC 8 and 20 hit points. They extend 5 feet above the water. Because the nets are wet, each has resistance to fire damage. Once a net drops to 0 hit points, the net sinks into the water and provides no impediment.

entries.name: Underwater Passage
entries: If the characters explore beneath the water, read the following:

Forty feet beneath the water, the walls are constructed of worked stone. Red and black mosaics of tentacles flank a set of black marble doors in the south wall. Reliefs of long, curving fangs line the arc of the door frame.
The double doors push open to reveal an underwater passage to area P4.

entries.name: P4. Temple Entrance
entries: The walls of this cavern are covered with slime and can't be climbed without gear, and the water here is fouled and unfit to drink.
The water fills the cavern to within 2 feet of the ceiling. The following boxed text assumes that the characters can see underwater:

Through the water looms a colonnade supporting an arched pediment above a long portico. Behind the colonnade is a pair of stone doors graven with a relief of a circular, saw-toothed maw. In the plaza in front of this structure, four slimy, fishlike humanoids kneel beneath a sunken stone idol of branching tentacles, which convene at the top around a circular fanged mouth.
At the southwestern end of the plaza, a set of curving stairs climbs above the water.
Four {@creature kuo-toa} worship at the altar, while a {@creature kuo-toa monitor} guards the northeast doors. The kuo-toa try to capture victims for their aboleth god (see area P6).

entries.name: Reinforcements
entries: If a battle occurs here, the creatures from area P7 investigate and join the fray.

entries.name: P5. Shrine of Yngukulub

entries: This room echoes with the roar of falling water. Relief carvings of horrific mouths, each framed by a knotwork of oozing tentacles wrought in stone, adorn the slime-covered walls of this half-submerged shrine.
Stairs lined with columns ascend from the water to a landing where a block of smooth stone serves as an altar. Chains snake from the base of the altar, ending in open, rusty manacles.
Three fish-like humanoids with jagged teeth stand around the altar. One wears a headdress of kelp and seashells, and it holds aloft a trident with tines shaped like tentacles.

This is where the aboleth in area P6 comes to feed on sacrifices. A {@creature kuo-toa archpriest} armed with a {@item trident of fish command} and two {@creature kuo-toa} attend their god here. They attempt to capture the characters and chain them to the altar. The rough-hewn landing on which the altar sits is 20 feet above water level.
Replace the kuo-toa archpriest's Scepter action with the following action:

entries.name: Trident of Fish Command
entries: {@atk mw,rw} +4 to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@i Hit}: 5 ({@dice 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage, or 6 ({@dice 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.
The walls of this cavern are covered with slime and can't be climbed without gear, and the water here is foul and unfit to drink.

entries.name: Reinforcements
entries: If the aboleth is in area P6, it crawls up to the landing and joins the battle.

entries.name: P6. Yngukulub the Devourer
entries: An {@creature aboleth} named Yngukulub the Devourer has allied itself with {@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA} and the Cult of the Crushing Wave. Deranged kuo-toa bring the aboleth sacrifices, and when they lack a proper sacrifice, they willingly feed themselves to their hungry god.

Yngukulub obeys {@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA} because it awaits the day when {@creature Olhydra|PotA} drowns the civilized world and crushes the temples of the gods. In the dark age that results from the triumph of {@creature Olhydra|PotA}, aboleths can return to their proper place as rulers of the world.
If {@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA} was defeated in the Temple of the Crushing Wave, the aboleth guards the water portal in area P20. Otherwise, it is here.

The slimy water that fills this cave flows through a hole in the east wall before plunging into the cavernous darkness beyond. Tall, slime-covered columns ascend from the foul water. Each one is decorated with a mosaic depicting elves, dwarves, humans, and other races descending into the fanged maw of a three-eyed, tentacled horror at the base of the column. The monster's eyes glitter like gems.

If it is here, the aboleth reaches out telepathically to the characters, promising to fulfill their desires in exchange for servitude. Characters who refuse are pulled down into the briny depths and devoured. The aboleth is heavily obscured by the dark, slimy water while completely submerged. It has no trouble pursuing prey that plunges over the waterfall to the east.

entries.name: Reinforcements
entries: The kuo-toa in area P5 come to the aboleth's defense if they aren't already dead.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The triple eyes of the aboleths depicted on the columns are actually emeralds, sapphires, and blue-green opals. The six gemstones are worth 1,000 gp apiece.
Lying on the floor of the aboleth's cave are 180 pp, 1,700 ep, and a{@item tentacle rod}.

entries.name: P7. Quipper Pit

entries: Stairs rise to a small, damp cave where five loathsome fishfolk stand around a pit, choking and muttering.
The pit is 10 feet wide and 40 feet down to the water. The water at the bottom of the pit is 10 feet deep (enough to cushion a fall).

Four {@creature kuo-toa} and a {@creature kuo-toa whip} have filled the pit with a {@creature swarm of quippers}. They ritually feed creatures to the quippers at times when they and the aboleth are sated. Their ritual is nonsense: gasping, muttering, and croaking with no basis in any known language. The kuo-toa attempt to push characters to the pit.

entries.name: P8. Sloping Cave

entries: Stalactites cover the ceiling of this cave, which slopes down toward the south. Embankments skirt the edges, and small, flat stones rise from the water, which is about 5 feet deep. Tiny white fish move through the shallows, darting over glittering coins visible beneath the water.

A {@creature roper} and four {@creature Piercer||piercers} cling to the cavern ceiling among the stalactites. A character who pays close attention to the stalactites and succeeds on a DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check spots the symbol of water etched into the creatures' tough flesh.

The roper attacks first. As it snares prey with its tendrils, it pulls its prey under the nearby piercers, which then drop from the ceiling. The piercers have advantage on attack rolls made against creatures {@condition grappled} by the roper.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Beneath the water are 230 ep and 563 gp.

entries.name: P9. Crushing Wave Outpost

entries: The ceiling of this large, water-filled cavern is 30 feet above the water's surface. In the middle of the cavern, two rocky plateaus rise twenty feet above the water. Atop each plinth crouches a humanoid with slimy, translucent skin. The water flows toward the southeast, where you hear a thunderous waterfall.
The water is only 5 feet deep in this cavern. The walls of the plateaus are wet but rough, and can be climbed with successful DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks.

Two {@creature Crushing Wave Reaver|PotA|Crushing Wave reavers} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}) keep watch atop the plateaus. Each has five javelins. They are slaves of the aboleth, and slime covers their translucent flesh. They aren't afraid to die.

Unless they are drawn to area P20 to protect the aboleth, two {@creature Chuul||chuuls} lurk behind the plateaus. They step out of hiding and attack interlopers as soon as the Crushing Wave reavers start hurling javelins. If a chuul paralyzes a foe, it allows the current to take the helpless creature over the falls and into area P20.

entries.name: P10. Trial by Water

entries: A ribbon of dry land hugs the walls of this cavern, the walls of which are covered with chalk-scrawled symbols of elemental water.

In the center of the cavern, a wrought-iron cage dangles from a rope lashed to a stalactite. Three-fourths of the cage hangs submerged in the pool that fills the middle of the cavern. A dozen humanoids pack the cage, elemental water's symbol raised in a scar on every brow. Tired hands grasp at the bars as the captives struggle to press their mouths above the water. Among the mass of wrestling forms, some lay still, floating face down inside the cage.
Eight {@creature Crushing Wave Reaver|PotA|Crushing Wave reavers} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}) occupy the cage with the drowned corpses of four other cultists.

{@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA} locked weak and disobedient cultists inside the cage in a ritual meant to strengthen them. The cultists attack if the characters free them, using bare hands until they can seize weapons. They surrender if reduced to half their number.

entries.name: P11. Hunter's Den

entries: Water drips from the stalactites in this serene cave, echoing through the gloom. Wide rock ledges extend around the perimeter, and natural stone islands provide ample room to sit or lay down.
This cave is the lair of a {@creature giant octopus}. It spends most of its time hunting, so it has only a ten percent chance each hour to be in its lair.
Submerged tunnels connect this cave to areas P12 and P18. Characters swimming underwater spot them automatically.

entries.name: Secret Passage
entries: A one-way secret door blocks access to a submerged tunnel that ends at another similar door. A successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check is sufficient to find either door, but they open only from the other side.

entries.name: P12. Feeding Cave

entries: A long pool fills the cavern, broken only by an island bristling with stalagmites. A corpse floats face down in the water near the island.
{@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA} uses this cave to dispose of those who oppose or displease him.

entries.name: Underwater Gate
entries: A submerged tunnel leads to area P13. This tunnel is blocked by a sturdy and locked iron gate. Four short iron chains ending in manacles are anchored to the iron bars of the gate. Using thieves' tools, a character can pick the lock with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check. The gate can also be wrenched open with a successful DC 25 Strength check.

entries.name: Drum
entries: A drum stands amid the stalagmites on the island. The cult uses the drum to alert the ghouls in area P13 when fresh meat awaits them.

entries.name: Floating Corpse
entries: The corpse belongs to a Crushing Wave initiate who got too close to the underwater gate while inspecting its manacles and was {@condition paralyzed} and clawed to death by the ghast in area P13. A search of the corpse reveals a ring with two keys—one that unlocks the gate, and another that unlocks the gate's manacles.

entries.name: Southern Area
entries: While exploring the southern part of this area, characters can hear the cackling of the mephits in area P14 above the roar of the falls. The temperature begins to drop the closer one moves toward area P14.

entries.name: P13. The Hungry

entries: Humanoid bones are scattered across the water's bottom. Barnacles cling to the cave walls, and piles of splintered bone crowd the cave's ledges and islands. The smell of brine battles with the stench of decay.
Seven {@creature Ghoul||ghouls} and a {@creature ghast} gnaw on the bones in this cave. When a creature enters their lair, the ghouls dive in to devour it and escape confinement.

entries.name: P14. Eye of Anguish

entries: Frosty mist fills this cave. Icicles and water crystals glitter along ledges, the ceiling, and the walls, and a brittle crust of ice surrounds a central isle upon which crouches a pale-skinned, bare-chested man wearing an eyepatch. He is surrounded by seven cackling, prancing, imp-like creatures made of ice. Five humans are spread-eagled against the far wall, frozen to its surface, their skin black from frostbite. Some hang upside down or sideways; some are missing fingers, hands, and feet.

A {@creature one-eyed shiver|PotA} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}) and seven {@creature Ice Mephit||ice mephits} inhabit this cave. The one-eyed shiver, called the Eye of Anguish by the other cultists, oversees the torture of prisoners. The ice mephits assist him.

entries.name: Frozen Prisoners
entries: The humans stuck on the cave wall are surfacers who learned too much about the Cult of the Crushing Wave or who stood in its way. A few could be adventurers who failed to stop the cult. Decide who these prisoners are, if any of them are alive, and what role you want them to play.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the battle here is extremely loud, the cultists in area P16 know to prepare for danger.

entries.name: P15. Reflection Chamber

entries: A throne made of coral and seashells stands on the rock at the center of this chamber. Across the arms of the throne, a pearl- and sapphire-encrusted narwhal horn rests like a lordly scepter. The smooth surface of the cavern's pool reflects the throne.
{@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA} uses this chamber as his personal retreat, where he reflects on the future of his cult.

The water here radiates divination magic under the scrutiny of a {@spell detect magic} spell. Once per day, when a creature touches the narwhal horn to the pool, a {@spell scrying} spell is instantaneously cast. The spell is limited to creatures and locations within the Plunging Torrents, allows no saving throw, and turns the pool's surface into a scrying sensor. If the horn's wielder doesn't specify a target before touching the horn to the pool, roll a {@dice d20}. The roll is the number of the area shown in the pool for the spell's duration. (For example, a roll of 9 focuses the scrying sensor on area P9.)
A submerged passage leads to area P14. Characters swimming underwater spot it automatically.

entries.name: Secret Passageway
entries: An underwater, one-way secret door swivels to allow access to a submerged tunnel leading northwest. Finding the door requires a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. A similar secret door at the end of the tunnel opens into area P11 and can be spotted without an ability check.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Encrusted with sapphires and pearls, the narwhal horn is worth 10,000 gp. A creature holding the narwhal horn in this cave feels it tug toward the reflective water.

entries.name: P16. Hut of the Dark Tide
entries: The waterfall at the southern end of this cave is audible from the northern approach.
A crude stone hut perches atop a stony island in the midst of a wide pool. Water drizzles from the cavern ceiling, and the roar of a waterfall echoes throughout.

Two {@creature Water Weird||water weirds} hidden beneath the water's surface serve as bonded mounts for two {@creature Dark Tide Knight|PotA|Dark Tide knights} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}) who live in the hut on the island. One knight is standing guard on the island when the characters first arrive; the other one is resting inside the hut.
The hut contains two hammocks made from fishing nets, as well as the knights' weapons, clothing, and belongings. None of these belongings are valuable.

entries.name: P17. Elemental Guardian

entries: Water pours into this cavern from a waterfall to the north, then flows over a second waterfall to the south. Thick mist conceals the cavern ceiling, with only an occasional stalactite piercing the fog. The surface of the water undulates in big, rolling waves.

The ceiling is 30 feet above the eater's surface. A {@creature water elemental myrmidon|MTF} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}) lurks under the water but rises to attack trespassers not dressed as water cultists.

entries.name: P18. Wrecks

entries: Heavy rain batters what must be a gigantic cavern, its walls and ceiling lost in the driving storm. Even the roar of the waterfalls to the north, west, and south hush beneath the rain's noise as it strikes the water.

At the center of the cavern, the shattered hulks of sailing vessels lean upon their sides. Barnacles cling to the hulls. Humanoid skeletons droop from the rigging or lay in tangled piles, and seaweed hangs from the gunwales.

The rain renders the entire area lightly obscured, and strong currents on either side of the wreckage pull toward areas P19a and P19b. Despite the enormity of the cavern, the water here is only 5 feet deep.
A {@creature hydra} nests among the wrecks, and it attacks any intruder that isn't {@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA}.

entries.name: Wrecked Ships
entries: {@creature Olhydra|PotA} channeled the power of the water node to deliver these vessels to {@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA} as a demonstration of her power. One of the wrecks is the Tethyrian merchant galley that once conscripted a young {@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA} into brutal indenture. The other is the same Calishite pirate vessel that attacked the Tethyrian merchant galley, an event that caused Gar to be cast adrift and lose his arm to a shark.

The wrecks form solid ground, but in most places they are {@quickref difficult terrain||3}, slick with rain where they aren't full of holes and splintered wood. Any character who attempts a complex maneuver, or takes the Dash or {@action Disengage} action, must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check or fall from the wreckage.
The ships lean on their sides. At your option, the ships might have multiple levels of vertical terrain, hanging sails, and tilting masts, which the characters can climb or use as walkways.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The Calishite pirate ship carries a chest laden with treasure. Characters searching the wreck find the chest, which contains a {@item +1 scimitar}, an {@item alchemy jug}, 1,200 gp, a diamond worth 5,000 gp, and two small rubies worth 1,000 gp each.

The hold of the Tethyrian merchant vessel is gutted, its supplies long gone. One of the skeletons aboard wears a suit of fine scale mail decorated with shell motifs. This scale mail is {@item mariner's armor}.

entries.name: P19a–P19b. Vortexes
entries: Strong currents channel water from area P18 to these caves. In the center of each cave is a swirling vortex. Any creature drawn down into the vortex is teleported to a random body of water within the Plunging Torrents. Roll a {@dice d20}; the number rolled determines of the location where the creature appears. For example, on a roll of 7, the creature teleports to the quipper pit in area P7.

entries.name: P20. Water Portal

entries: An island rises from a lake at the epicenter of three roaring waterfalls. Flutes of rose, ivory, and lavender coral fringe the island. Above the island floats a gigantic, shimmering globe of water. Smaller globes of water emerge from it, drift outward, and hover in the air a few feet above the surface of the lake. The ambient light reveals the cavern ceiling, eighty feet above the island and hung with countless stalactites.
The cave floor gradually rises toward the island, such that the water is 20 feet deep at the cave perimeter and only 5 feet deep within 10 feet of the island.

If the characters previously defeated {@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA}, use the "Encounter with the Aboleth" section. If Gar has retreated to the node and the characters have defeated two other elemental prophets, use the "Encounter with {@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA}" section. If Gar is the sole remaining prophet, use the "Encounter with {@creature Olhydra|PotA}" section.

entries.name: Water Globes
entries: When the characters first arrive, three 7-foot-diameter globes of water drift about this cavern. Each globe of water floats 1 foot above water level and is stationary until a creature touches it, whereupon it envelops the creature and carries it to area P1 via the north tunnel (passing though areas P18, P17, and P2). The globe has a flying speed of 10 feet, and a creature contained within gains the benefit of a {@spell water breathing} spell for as long as it remains in the globe. Any time during the trip, the creature inside the globe can swim out of it as an action. The globe carries only the one creature and bursts upon reaching its destination. A globe is immune to damage, though {@item dust of dryness} destroys it.
If a globe is destroyed or leaves this cave, another one emerges from the water portal to take its place.

entries.name: Encounter with the Aboleth
entries: The {@creature aboleth} from area P6 and the two {@creature Chuul||chuuls} from area P9 guard the portal. The creatures are submerged in the southwest corner of the cave when the characters first arrive. The aboleth hopes to kill or enslave the characters, seize {@item Drown|PotA}, and replace {@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA} as {@creature Olhydra|PotA}'s prophet.

entries.name: Encounter with Gar Shatterkeel
entries: {@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}) stands on the island before the water portal, beginning his ritual to call forth {@creature Olhydra|PotA}. He is guarded by a {@creature water elemental} and three {@creature Crocodile||crocodiles} that circle the island, attacking any creatures that approach.

Gar makes a final stand here. He can't retreat to the Plane of Water with {@item Drown|PotA}, and he refuses to abandon his grim mission. When the characters defeat him, he turns to inky water and courses away. {@item Drown|PotA} remains where he fell.

entries.name: Encounter with Olhydra
entries: {@creature Gar Shatterkeel|PotA} stands on the island, unguarded. He holds his trident aloft and cries, "With this key I call forth my mistress!" A dark flow emerges from the portal, forming an immense water elemental with pearly, malignant eyes. This is {@creature Olhydra|PotA}, Princess of Evil Water (see {@area chapter 7|728|x}). {@creature Olhydra|PotA} focuses on remaining in the world to work evil, especially keeping {@item Drown|PotA} away from the characters.

entries.name: Rising Water
entries: When {@creature Olhydra|PotA} appears, the water in the lake rises 2 feet at the end of each round. Since the waterfalls in the cavern are 40 feet high, the lake rises to the level of areas P9, P16, and P18 after 20 rounds. Once the water reaches the tops of the waterfalls, the water stops at 60 feet deep.

entries.name: The Water Portal
entries: The water portal is a 13-foot-diameter globe of water that floats above the island.

Characters who pass through the portal arrive underwater on the Elemental Plane of Water, where {@creature Olhydra|PotA} comes forth to destroy them. Characters can retreat through the portal; however, {@creature Olhydra|PotA} can't pass through the portal until the ritual is complete.

Characters can close the portal only by hurling {@item Drown|PotA} into it, destroying {@item Drown|PotA} in the process. If the portal closes while {@creature Olhydra|PotA} remains in the world, she is forced back to the Plane of Water. No more watery globes form within the Plunging Torrents, and the water in the node returns to normal levels. Over the course of the next few days, much of the remaining water siphons out into the surrounding earth.

entries.name: The Black Geode
entries: The Black Geode is a natural cavern distinguished by the seams of luminous violet crystal. {@creature Marlos Urnrayle|PotA} used {@item Ironfang|PotA} to transform these caverns into an earth node. In the Black Geode's largest cavern lies a portal that leads to {@creature Ogrémoch|PotA}'s domain on the Elemental Plane of Earth. Bizarre creatures from that place have crossed through the gate and now inhabit the caverns, while the raw energy of the elemental plane seeps out and is slowly transforming the Black Geode into a reflection of {@creature Ogrémoch|PotA}'s domain.

entries.name: Geode Features
entries: The area has the following features. Any exceptions are noted in areas to which they apply.

entries.name: Character Recognition
entries: Even if he has not yet encountered the characters, Marlos has seen them in his visions. The earth prophet gives descriptions of the characters to all cultists in the Black Geode.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Cavern ceilings are 30 feet high, while tunnels are 15 feet high.

entries.name: Light
entries: Most areas are dimly lit by crystal formations that give off a soft, violet glow.

entries.name: Random Encounters
entries: Check for random encounters once every 30 minutes. Roll a {@dice d20} and consult the following table to determine what, if anything, the characters encounter:

rows: 1 {@creature burrowshark|PotA} riding a {@creature bulette} (see area G13)
1 {@creature stonemelder|PotA} and {@dice 1d3 + 1} {@creature Black Earth Guard|PotA|Black Earth guards} (see area G12)
1 {@creature umber hulk} (bursts out of a nearby wall)

entries.name: Bleeding Earth
entries: A nearby wall swells and splits open, oozing thick black mud.

entries.name: Ceiling Collapse
entries: A tremor causes part of the ceiling to collapse above one random party member. If the party includes NPCs, be sure to count them as well. The target must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 21 ({@dice 6d6}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone} and buried. While buried in this way, the target is {@condition restrained} and unable to breathe or stand up. A creature can take an action to extricate itself or another buried creature, doing so with a successful DC 15 Strength check.

entries.name: Crystal Extrusion
entries: A crack splits open on a nearby wall, extruding foot-long, luminous violet crystals.

entries.name: Fissure
entries: A tremor causes a fissure {@dice 1d6 × 10} feet deep to open in the floor beneath one party member (determined randomly). If the party includes NPCs, be sure to count them as well. The affected party member must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or fall into the fissure, taking bludgeoning damage as normal unless it is tied off or otherwise protected against falling. The walls of the fissure are rough and can be climbed with a successful DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: Flowstone Growth
entries: Stalactites within 30 feet of the party begin to drip like melting wax. By the time the change ceases, each stalactite has grown {@dice 1d4} feet longer. If a stalactite touches the opposite surface, it becomes a natural column.

entries.name: G1. Hall of the Guardians
entries: This cave lies at the end of a twisting, declining tunnel that began in area F13 of the Fane of the Eye.

The rough walls of this cavern rise to a vaulted ceiling hung with stalactites and clumps of slender, luminous crystals that bathe the cavern in a soft, violet light. Passages lead east and west. To the east, the tunnel ascends. The western passage is flanked by a pair of twenty-foot tall stone statues of rough-hewn humanoids, their faces grim masks of forbiddance. Next to each statue is a human guard encased in stone armor.

Two {@creature Black Earth Guard|PotA|Black Earth guards} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}) stand in front of the statues. Characters not wearing disguises are recognized for who they really are. Characters disguised as earth cultists or cult prisoners must make a Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check contested by the guards' Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks; if all the characters succeed, the guards are fooled and allow them to pass.

If combat erupts here, two {@creature Earth Elemental||earth elementals} burst up from the middle of the floor and join the battle. These elementals have veins of glowing purple crystal; each sheds bright light in a 15-foot radius and dim light for another 15 feet beyond that.

entries.name: G2. Keltar and Gorx

entries: The walls of this circular chamber are thick with glowing crystals. In the middle of the room is a fat, egg-shaped creature with three arms, three legs, heavy-lidded eyes, and a wide mouth atop its stony ovoid body. Casually dropping gemstones into the creature's gaping mouth is a creepy-looking earth cultist.

A {@creature stonemelder|PotA} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}) named Keltar keeps vigil with a {@creature xorn} he discovered hiding in area G17. If the characters attack either, both retaliate in kind. The xorn flees once it has fewer than 20 hit points, but Keltar fights to the death.

entries.name: Roleplaying Keltar
entries: Keltar believes the xorn, called Gorx, is an emissary from {@creature Ogrémoch|PotA} sent to test the cult's worth. In fact, the creature wandered through the earth portal out of curiosity. Since Keltar was eager to please Gorx, it has done nothing to dissuade him.

The xorn has convinced Keltar that {@creature Ogrémoch|PotA} wants tribute, and so Keltar extracts offerings from everyone who passes through. Keltar is so obsessed with offerings that he ignores the appearance of passersby and the usual pass phrase. When he notices the characters, he asks, "Do you bring an offering?"
Making an offering involves throwing precious metals or gems into the xorn's maw. Keltar soberly informs contributors the treasure is transported to {@creature Ogrémoch|PotA}'s domain.

The xorn can smell the party's wealth, and so it demands a tribute of 500 gp in Terran. If the party complies, Keltar asks, "Is our prince satisfied with the offering?" to which Gorx replies, "The prince finds this sacrifice pleasing." Keltar believes the xorn has deemed the party worthy, so he allows them to pass. He also helpfully responds to inquiries. If the characters are undisguised, he directs them toward area G3, as another test of their worthiness. Keltar directs the characters toward area G6 if he believes them to be cultists and also reminds them of the pass phrase to cross the stone bridge (area G9) safely: "We walk in the shadow of {@creature Ogrémoch|PotA}!"
If the characters refuse to pay, the xorn attacks the character carrying the most treasure. Meanwhile, Keltar flees to area G6.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The xorn's stomach still contains some undigested offerings: 9 gp, three egg-sized chunks of rough moonstone worth 25 gp each, three carnelians worth 50 gp each, and a cracked amethyst worth 100 gp. Keltar carries two more carnelians and hides a folded scroll of {@spell investiture of stone|XGE} (see {@adventure appendix B|PotA|8}) in a pocket.

entries.name: G3. Roper Den

entries: This cave is a thicket of stalagmites and stalactites. Several weapons and broken pieces of armor lie scattered among the spires in the room's center.

A {@creature roper} hangs from the ceiling above the debris. It ate several cultists before the others started avoiding the area. Eager for more humanoid flesh, the roper attempts to subdue as many of the adventurers as it can. It closes its eye and retracts it tendrils when reduced to 20 hit points, hoping the characters leave it alone.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Scattered amid the broken weapons and armor are 65 gp, a brass statuette of an imp with onyx eyes worth 180 gp, and a {@item ring of swimming}.

entries.name: G4. Bewildering Crystals

entries: This cave is a forest of glowing crystals, which grow like foliage on slender stone columns that make it difficult to gauge the chamber's true size. Slumped against one of the columns is a dead man wearing a stone breastplate.

Any creature entering the cave for the first time on a turn or starting its turn inside must succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw or suffer the effects of a {@spell confusion} spell. Once a creature succeeds on its saving throw, it is immune to this effect for 24 hours.

A thunderous noise emanates from the northeast tunnel, which is only 5 feet high and slopes gently upward to area G6. The tunnel ends at a wall of falling mud (see area G6). Any creature passing under the mud takes 10 ({@dice 3d6}) bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Corpse
entries: The corpse belongs to a Black Earth guard killed by one of his fellow cultists. The guard carries nothing of value.

entries.name: Secret Passage
entries: The "secret" entrance to area G5 is a tunnel cloaked by a 6th-level {@spell major image} spell to look like a solid stone wall. Discovering its nature from a distance requires a DC 19 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check, although direct interaction immediately reveals the illusion.

entries.name: G5. Underdark Entrance

entries: A hole in the back of this cave forms the mouth of a tunnel that plunges deeper into the earth. The tunnel is devoid of the luminous crystals that grow elsewhere in these caverns, and a chill, fetid breeze wafts up from its depths.
This tunnel runs for miles, eventually branching off into the caves of the Underdark.

entries.name: G6. Mudflow Falls

entries: The dull roar of splashing, churning mud fills this cavern, the walls and ceiling of which are streaked with glittering veins of glowing violet crystal. A stream of mud pours through a gash in the roof, cascades down until it crashes onto a ten-foot-high ledge, then tumbles over the ledge into a thin river of mud that flows out through a hole in the northeast corner. A stone staircase climbs up to the ledge, where a passage leads north. A tunnel on the lower level leads south.

Earth cultists call this river of elemental mud the Mudflow. The river is 6 feet wide, 3 feet deep, and descends a total of 40 feet by the time it reaches area G11. Any creature that enters the river for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there must make a DC 10 Strength saving throw or fall {@condition prone} and be swept 20 feet toward area G11. A creature that is {@condition prone} in the mud must use an action and succeed on a DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to stand up. Standing isn't possible within the section of tunnel between this cave and area G11; that stretch of the river is completely submerged in mud.
A creature can use an action to pull itself or another creature within its reach out of the Mudflow, doing so on a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.
Every 1 foot of movement through the mud costs 2 feet of speed, 5 feet if the creature is trying to move against the flow.

entries.name: Hidden Tunnel
entries: A 5-foot-high tunnel hidden behind the mud descends to area G4. A creature must pass through the mud to reach the tunnel, taking 10 ({@dice 3d6}) bludgeoning damage from the falling mud.

entries.name: Ledge
entries: The western portion of the cave is 10 feet higher than the eastern portion, and the ledge can be scaled with a successful DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. The stone staircase leading up to the ledge is on the north side of the Mudflow.

entries.name: G7. Empty Cave

entries: This small cave is striated with glowing violet crystals. A tunnel to the south turns sharply eastward, while a tunnel to the north slopes down and toward the east as well.
This area is perfect for random encounters.

entries.name: G8. Cavern of the Lost Crown
entries: As the party approaches this area for the first time, read the following text:
Bloodcurdling screams come from the cave ahead. The cries last only a few seconds, then stop suddenly.
Once the party can see the cave, read the following:

Humanoid bones litter the floor of this cavern. Some skeletons are partially intact, their rib cages shattered by boulders lying atop them. Only one skeleton remains whole, and it clutches to its chest an open-faced steel helmet decorated with a golden circlet above the brow, from which seven small gold spikes project upward.

The crowned helmet is an ancient dwarven relic (see "Treasure" below) that radiates strong magic when scrutinized with a {@spell detect magic} spell. As soon as someone tries to take it, the {@creature ghost} of a duergar treasure hunter named Reulek appears and uses his Horrifying Visage, screaming, "Thieves! Learn from my folly! Even in death, the dwarves of Besilmer guard their fabled treasure!" As the ghost intones these words, four {@creature Specter||specters} of dead drow killed here long ago in a cave collapse materialize and attack the living.

entries.name: Roleplaying Reulek
entries: Earth cultists found the crowned helmet in the Temple of Black Earth but failed to realize its significance. Reulek later stole it and was sneaking toward area G5 when he fell prey to the specters in this cave.
Reulek believes the specters killed him for stealing the helmet. His soul is bound to the relic by the thought that he must return it to its rightful owner before going to his eternal rest.

If the adventurers defeat the specters and talk to the ghost, Ruelek explains his predicament. If the characters point out the specters weren't dwarves and probably didn't care about the crown, Reulek admits that his death may have had nothing to do with the relic. He knows that the remains of the last king of Besilmer are beneath the Halls of the Hunting Axe. He asks the characters to help him return the crowned helm to the king's tomb. Characters who agree find that Reulek accompanies them through his connection to the relic, although he manifests only when you wish him to do so.

If the party refuses to help, or if at any point Reulek gets the sense that they aren't going to follow through on their promise, he uses Possession to enforce the agreement. If the party stays true to the bargain, Reulek's spirit thanks them as he goes to his rest.

Reulek was the partner of an oni named Obratu (see "{@area Vale of Dancing Waters|6a7|x}" in chapter 6). The characters might recognize his name from the note they find if they defeat Obratu. Reulek shrugs if the characters mention Obratu, saying, "It was a partnership of convenience."

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The golden-spiked helm is the {@item Lost Crown of Besilmer|PotA} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6|Lost Crown of Besilmer}).

entries.name: G9. Narrow Stone Bridge
entries: The following boxed text assumes that the characters arrive here via the tunnel to the north or south:
The passage opens onto a smooth stone bridge flanked by boulders. The bridge is five feet wide, has no railings, and spans a wide cavern that echoes with strange clacking noises.

The bridge is 40 feet long and sturdy. A creature on the bridge that takes 10 damage or more from a single source must make a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw. If the save fails by 5 or more, the creature is knocked off the bridge and falls. On any other failed result, the creature is knocked {@condition prone} but manages not to fall off the bridge. The bridge is 40 feet above the floor of the surrounding cavern (area G10).

Two {@creature Galeb Duhr||galeb duhrs} guard the bridge—one at each end. They look like ordinary boulders until they open their eyes and move. To cross the bridge without rousing the galeb duhrs, someone among the passersby must speak the cult's pass phrase: "We walk in the shadow of {@creature Ogrémoch|PotA}!" Otherwise, the galeb duhrs wait until intruders are halfway across the bridge before attacking, first by animating the boulders set near them and commanding them to roll across the bridge.
The clacking noises are made by the hook horrors in the surrounding cavern.

entries.name: Reinforcements
entries: Combat on the bridge attracts the hook horrors in area G10, which gather under the bridge and attack any creature that falls.

entries.name: G10. Clickety Clack

entries: This long cavern cuts a wide swath through the earth. Its jagged walls look as if the stone here tore itself apart. Shattered bones lie amid the scree. High above, a narrow stone bridge spans the defile. The chasm echoes with clacking noises that sound a little like falling rocks.
The cavern ceiling is 80 feet high, and the bridge (area G9) is 40 feet above the cavern floor.

Eight {@creature Hook Horror||hook horrors} hide in crevices along the walls, communicating with one another using a series of indecipherable clicks and clacks. The hook horrors attack any creature that tries to cross their territory or falls from the bridge.

entries.name: Secret Way
entries: Hidden at the back of one hook horror's crevice is a narrow passage leading 20 feet up to area G7. The opening to this tunnel requires a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to spot, although a character who explores the crevice by entering it finds the hidden tunnel without an ability check.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters who search through the shattered bones of the hook horrors' previous victims find 17 sp, four pieces of blue quartz (10 gp each), a silver hand mirror inlaid with lapis lazuli (270 gp), and a {@i pearl of power}.

entries.name: G11. Elemental Mud Pool

entries: A river of thick mud gushes from a fissure in one wall, running a short way before gathering into a swirling pool. Standing next to the pool is an earth elemental encased in armor and several small creatures composed of thick, dripping mud.
The river of mud flows into this cavern from area G6.

An {@creature earth elemental myrmidon|MTF} (see {@adventure chapter 7|PotA|6}) stands guard, ignoring the taunts of six {@creature Mud Mephit||mud mephits}. The myrmidon is protective of the pool and attacks intruders. The mephits join in, but unlike the myrmidon, each one reduced to fewer than 10 hit points flees.

See area G6 for rules about moving through the river of mud. A creature that ends its turn in the swirling pool must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be sucked down into the Elemental Plane of Earth and lost. A creature tethered by a rope can be pulled 10 feet toward the edge of the pool with a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the characters observe the cave unnoticed for a few minutes, they see the myrmidon lean over the pool and pluck a fledgling {@creature mud mephit} from the muck. The pool has a noncumulative five percent chance of spawning a new mud mephit each hour.

entries.name: G12. Hall of Meditation
